DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Bjt
Administration Moves Against Assets Held By Noriega
Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, In Bern, with two grafs to update with French action, picks up 5th graf pvs, The Swiss
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department asked four European nations Wednesday to freeze bank accounts where former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega is thought to have hidden illegal drug profits. David Runkel, a department spokesman, said the legal papers were filed with the governments of France, Switzerland, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom, requesting authorities to order banks to block any transactions in the Noriega accounts. ``The request is of money directly tied to his alleged illegal drug trafficking,'' Runkel said, adding there is ``more than one account in each country.'' Authorities in France responded to the U.S. request by freezing accounts in two banks holding $3.3 million under the names of Noriega and members of his families. Swiss officials placed a ``precautionary'' freeze on two accounts in banks in Zurich and Geneva. French investigators said the banks in France may have been used as transit points for funds destined for Luxembourg or Switzerland. The Swiss Justice Ministry said the U.S. request charged Noriega with giving ``logistic support'' to Colombian drug lords' shipments to the United States. Noriega, who is hiding in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City, is thought to have transferred at least $10 million into numerous accounts in Europe, Runkel said. State Department officials, however, say Noriega's personal wealth could total as much as $300 million. Deposed as dictator by U.S. troops on Dec. 20, Noriega has been charged in Florida in two drug trafficking indictments. Runkel said department lawyers are confident they can document that money Noriega sent abroad had been earned illegally in the drug trade. U.S. troops seized a slew of records in Panama City after Noriega was ousted. The four European countries are expected to cooperate with the American request, rules of which are spelled out in international treaties. ``We have had a remarkable display of international cooperation,'' Runkel said. ``These letters were not sprung on these countries this morning.'' Once the bank accounts have been frozen _ as Justice expects _ there is still the possibility they will be barren, Runkel said. It's conceivable, he said, that Noriega, his family or his bankers moved money out of accounts since the invasion. Freezing assets is the first step to seizing them, said Runkel. ``These things are not easy processes.'' Any disposition of the money, however, would be by international agreements. Preliminary discussions were also under way with others countries where Noriega might has stashed money, Runkel said. But he is not thought to have assets in the United States. State Department estimates put Noriega's worth at between $200 million to $300 million, much of it hidden in secret bank accounts abroad. In a speech last August, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger alluded to multimillion-dollar transactions Noriega has made over the past two years involving accounts in West Germany, Switzerland and Luxembourg. The private gains Noriega has accumulated, Eagleburger said, belie the image he has projected of a ``poor youth of humble origins who by virtue of individual effort, merit and talent rose through the ranks to become head of a small but respectable military force.''
